The picture may have initially been titled Shadow of Columbus or In the Shadow of Columbus, according to a 5 Aug 1959 DV article, which noted the film, now titled The Big Gamble, would be based on Irwin Shaw’s “new novel” and that production was set to take place in Italy; the Azores in Portugal; Chile; and Hollywood, CA. However, Shaw did not publish a book with either of the aforementioned titles, and his script for The Big Gamble was described as an “original screenplay” in the 2 Sep 1961 NYT review.

The project was part of a ten-picture slate to be produced by Darryl F. Zanuck Productions, Inc., in 1959 and 1960. Richard Fleischer was brought on to direct, as reported in the 6 Feb 1960 NYT, and the budget was set at $4 million. The 12 Feb 1960 and 14 Mar 1960 issues of DV stated that production would be located in Africa; Dublin, Ireland; London, England; and France, where some shooting was scheduled to take place at Studios de Boulogne in Paris.

As indicated in conflicting reports in the 27 May 1960 DV, principal photography began in Paris on 23 May 1960 or 25 May 1960. An item in the 9 Jun 1960 DV stated that production had just relocated to Dublin, where eleven days of shooting were planned. Cast and crew returned to France for filming in the southern part of the country, where locations standing in for Africa included sections of the Camargue; Vallon-Pont-d’Arc; Port-de-Bouc; Arles; and rock caves below the town of Les Baux. In an interview published in the 14 Aug 1960 NYT, Zanuck claimed France was used as much as possible due to the difficulties of shooting in Africa, which he had experienced firsthand on the set of The Roots of Heaven (1958, see entry). Zanuck was concerned about the heat, threat of dysentery and fever, and primitive living conditions that his cast and crew would be subjected to, but acknowledged that, for verisimilitude, a certain amount of filming had to take place in the Ivory Coast cities of Abidjan, Sassandra, and Grand-Bassam. An 8 Jan 1961 LAT article also quoted Zanuck as saying that the film company were “worried about cannibalism,” since it was known to be a practice there.

While filming in Vallon-Pont-d’Arc, actor Stephen Boyd slipped and struck his head upon jumping into the River Ardèche, in a scene in which he was supposed to free a truck from the water. As noted in the 5 Jul 1960 LAT, co-star David Wayne saved Boyd from drowning after he slid under the water unconscious.

Production was scheduled to move to the Ivory Coast on 7 Aug 1960, a day which marked the country’s independence from France. African locations were completed by mid-Aug 1960, when cast and crew travelled to London for filming at Twickenham Studios, the 17 Aug 1960 Var noted. There, the final three weeks of shooting were set to take place, with an emphasis on process shots, which were done in a far superior manner there as opposed to the U.S., according to Zanuck in the 8 Jan 1961 LAT.

An article in the 28 Jun 1960 DV noted that The Big Gamble was shot in Cinemascope using Eastman Kodak’s new 52-50 superspeed color negative. Despite recent complaints about the film stock from filmmaker Stanley Donen, Fleischer and director of photography William C. Mellor were said to be happy with its capacity to extend “clarity and definition to the outer edges of the frame to an extent never before realized” with the Cinemascope process.

Phil Gersdorf served as unit publicist, as stated in the 8 Jun 1960 Var. Although he did not receive onscreen credit, Gersdorf’s name was said to appear on “300 cartons and 7,200 cans of beer” used as props, according to a 21 Jul 1960 DV brief. Also working on the crew were French-Belgian film director Jacques Feyder’s three sons, as pointed out in the 3 Aug 1960 Var: assistant directors Paul Feyder and Bernard Farrel, and Marc Feyder, who acted as assistant to the art director.

Irish seaman Vic Brennan persuades his Dublin family to finance a truck-hauling business in the remote African town of Jebanda. The only stipulation is that his cousin Samuel, a timid bank clerk, accompany Vic and his Corsican bride, Marie, to Africa and protect the family fortune. When the trio arrive at a small settlement on the Ivory Coast, Samuel loses their customs papers, and their truck is impounded. Fortunately, Marie meets an old friend, a French naval lieutenant; and despite Vic's jealous nature, she uses her wiles to get the truck released from custody. Before they leave, Vic buys 300 cases of beer, certain he can double his money once they reach Jebanda. After a short time on the road, the truck crashes against a fallen tree. Vic, however, resourcefully rounds up some natives to remove the tree in return for a few cases of beer. Further on, they encounter a gruff German, Hans Kaltenberg, who offers to be their guide and then tries to steal their cargo; but Vic overpowers him and drives him off. The blazing African sun eventually proves too much for Samuel, and he comes down with a fever. As Marie cares for him, he deliriously declares his love for her. Irish seaman Vic Brennan persuades his Dublin family to finance a truck-hauling business in the remote African town of Jebanda. The only stipulation is that his cousin Samuel, a timid bank clerk, accompany Vic and his Corsican bride, Marie, to Africa and protect the family fortune. When the trio arrive at a small settlement on the Ivory Coast, Samuel loses their customs papers, and their truck is impounded. Fortunately, Marie meets an old friend, a French naval lieutenant; and despite Vic's jealous nature, she uses her wiles to get the truck released from custody. Before they leave, Vic buys 300 cases of beer, certain he can double his money once they reach Jebanda. After a short time on the road, the truck crashes against a fallen tree. Vic, however, resourcefully rounds up some natives to remove the tree in return for a few cases of beer. Further on, they encounter a gruff German, Hans Kaltenberg, who offers to be their guide and then tries to steal their cargo; but Vic overpowers him and drives him off. The blazing African sun eventually proves too much for Samuel, and he comes down with a fever. As Marie cares for him, he deliriously declares his love for her. By the time his fever has abated, the truck has reached a raging river. While crossing, Vic is knocked unconscious by a log and sent reeling downstream. Samuel suddenly finds the courage and strength to drag his cousin ashore. As they start down a steep hillside, the brakes of the truck give way, and it crashes between two trees and turns over. However, the trio discover that Jebanda is just ahead.
